clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is built on seven hills and has a tiny country within its borders.
Ancient gladiators once fought in a massive stone amphitheater here.
fun_fact: People throw about €1.5 million into the Trevi Fountain each year, which is collected and donated to charity.
Rome has more than 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Pantheon in this city has the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome, built nearly 2,000 years ago.
This city's first university, La Sapienza, was founded in 1303 and is one of the largest in Europe.

clues: This harbor city is known for its iconic opera house with sail-shaped roofs.
It hosts the world's largest natural harbor and a famous New Year's Eve fireworks display.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build, 10 years longer than expected.
Sydney's Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world, with lifeguards rescuing about 2,500 people per year.
trivia: Sydney Tower is the city's tallest structure and the second tallest observation tower in the Southern Hemisphere.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its distinctive arch-based design.

clues: This city sits near some of the world's most famous triangular stone structures.
The world's longest river flows through this ancient metropolis.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza, located on the outskirts of this city, is the only surviving structure of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
Cairo's Al-Azhar University, founded in 970 CE, is one of the oldest continuously operating universities in the world.
trivia: The Egyptian Museum in this city contains more than 120,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts, including treasures from Tutankhamun's tomb.
Cairo's Khan el-Khalili bazaar has been operating since the 14th century.

clues: This city is known for a massive statue of Christ with outstretched arms overlooking the bay.
It hosts the world's largest and most famous carnival celebration.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning several times a year and has special lightning rods installed.
Copacabana Beach stretches for 2.5 miles and uses a distinctive black and white Portuguese wave pattern in its promenade.
trivia: This city was once the capital of Portugal, the only European capital to exist outside of Europe.
The Maracanã Stadium once held nearly 200,000 people for the 1950 World Cup final, the largest crowd ever at a sporting event.

clues: This city has more bridges than Venice and more canals than anywhere else in the world.
Famous for its narrow houses, bicycle culture, and museums dedicated to artists like Van Gogh.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more than 1,200 bridges crossing its 165 canals.
Houses in Amsterdam are narrow because historically property taxes were based on the width of the building's facade.
trivia: Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport is built on land that was once at the bottom of the sea.
The Anne Frank House is one of the city's most visited museums, preserving the hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her famous diary.

clues: This desert city is home to the world's tallest building and artificial islands shaped like palm trees.
Once a small fishing village, it's now known for luxury shopping, ultramodern architecture, and indoor ski slopes.
fun_fact: Police in this city drive luxury cars including Lamborghinis, Ferraris, and Bentleys.
The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset from the base, then take the elevator to the top and watch it set again.
trivia: This city has the world's largest choreographed fountain system, with water jets that shoot up to 500 feet in the air.
Gold is so common in the souks (markets) here that there's an entire market nicknamed 'The City of Gold.'

clues: This unique city is built on 118 small islands connected by over 400 bridges.
Instead of roads, this city uses waterways and boats for transportation.
fun_fact: Venice is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year.
The Venice Carnival dates back to the 12th century and is famous for its elaborate masks.
trivia: There are no cars or roads in Venice's historic center, making it the largest urban car-free area in Europe.
The city's famous gondolas are always painted black, by law, except for those belonging to high government officials.
